text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single column of text occupying upper two-thirds of the page, followed by a full-width rectangular miniature at the bottom. A large ornamental initial in blue and gold marks the beginning of the rubric and new section. Narrow margins with ruling visible; text and image separated by a thin ruled line.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata, professional book hand with consistent letterforms, pronounced angularity, extensive use of abbreviations and ligatures

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf reserved for divine and high-status elements (tapestry pattern, bishop’s mitre), layered over raised gesso. Ultramarine and azurite used in royal garments and background canopy, emphasizing hierarchy. Vermilion red dominates tapestry wall, contrasting with cool greens in vestments and floor. White highlights applied to drapery folds for volume. Pigments remain well-preserved with minimal darkening.

features: Central baptismal font as focal point
Symmetrical arrangement of figures around font
Gestural lines (staff, arms) direct attention to water pouring

decorative_elements: Red diapered tapestry background with scrolling vines
Blue and gold canopy with foliate pattern
Ornamental initial in text in blue, gold, red
Architectural framing with twin arches and columns

drawing_technique.line_style: Fine quill outlines in dark brown ink, fluid yet controlled, with bolder contours for main figures
drawing_technique.shading_method: Subtle wash layering with white highlights on robes and faces, minimal hatching indicating folds
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Shallow, stage-like perspective; overlapping figures suggest depth without true vanishing point; slight hierarchical scaling of bishop

content_theme.scene_description: The single scene depicts the baptism of an infant at a marble font. Centrally placed, the font is supported on a pedestal; water is poured by a deacon from a silver ewer held aloft, while a bishop wearing a gold-leafed mitre, green cope with red lining, and holding a gilded crosier stands to the right. Four child acolytes kneel before the font in white albs, each holding a linen towel. To the left, a crowned queen in an ermine-lined fleur-de-lis cloak and a cleric sponsor stand reverently; behind them, additional clerics in white albs observe. An angelic cherub’s head emerges from the tapestry canopy overhead, symbolizing the Holy Spirit. The background is an interior with twin Gothic arches revealing distant rolling hills and city spires, and a red tapestry wall. Figures are arranged symmetrically, gestures converging on the font, with scale and attire distinguishing hierarchy.

symbolic: angelic cherub head representing the Holy Spirit

architectural: twin Gothic arches with alternating colored voussoirs
pillars supporting barrel-vaulted ceiling with painted ribs
natural: stylized rolling hills visible through left arch
distant city skyline with spires through right arch

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum, uniformly thin and smooth, with faint hair follicle pattern; ruled by plummet and pricked for even line spacing; quaternion gathering.
technical_features.preservation_condition: Vivid pigments with minimal oxidation; slight pigment flaking at red tapestry edges; gold leaf intact; very slight cockling at corners; evidence of modern stabilization.
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso under gold leaf in canopy and mitre
Regular pricking and ruling lines for text layout

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This manuscript leaf, likely produced in a French court workshop c. 1400–1420, illustrates the baptism of a royal infant, combining vernacular hagiographic text with a richly illuminated sacramental scene. The use of ultramarine and burnished gold leaf, applied over raised gesso, suggests a highly resourced atelier, while the formal Gothic textura script indicates professional scribes. The tapestry-like background and architectural framing recall the influence of the Parisian and Île-de-France illumination traditions, yet the balanced color scheme and naturalistic glimpses through the arches nod to developments on the Loire Valley circuit. Iconographically, the pairing of the crowned sponsor with the angelic cherub overhead reinforces the link between royal patronage and divine favor, embedding political messaging within a religious narrative. Compared to contemporary Books of Hours for the nobility, this scene places greater emphasis on ecclesiastical hierarchy, as seen in the bishop’s prominent placement and the deacon’s active role. The manuscript’s preservation, with intact gold and vibrant pigments, points to high-quality materials and careful conservation. In comparative perspective, its stylistic affinities align with the Bedford Master’s circle, though the restrained modeling and subtle hatching suggest a localized workshop. Overall, this illumination exemplifies the synthesis of devotional function, courtly representation, and technical virtuosity characteristic of early fifteenth-century French illumination.
